Award.AwardTitle: Unimolecular Micelles: Design, Synthesis, and Properties
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Douglas Adamson of the University of Connecticut will synthesize and study polymers that can form stable, single chain globules in solution. Natural proteins, in a very general sense, are polymers containing mostly hydrophobic monomers and a relatively thin layer of hydrophilic monomers at the surface of the protein globule. It has been predicted that single chain polymer globules can be stabilized to aggregation and precipitation if they possess this type of morphology. To test this prediction, polymers will be synthesized that contain a hydrophobic main chain and a set number of hydrophilic grafts serving to stabilize the single polymer chain against flocculation and precipitation. The design of the polymer architecture will be driven and informed by theoretical work that predicts the effect of the placement and type of hydrophilic components on the stability and morphology of the synthesized polymer. The broader impacts such research include increasing our understanding of the folding and morphology of proteins, as well as opening the door for synthetic materials that may perform some of the functions of proteins. In addition, the project will involve visits to local schools and will contribute to the training of undergraduate and graduate students.

The creation of precisely defined structures that have dimensions on the order of nanometers (termed "nanostructures") continues to be a challenge for chemists. Nature has perfected many methods to assembly nanostructures, including the folding of proteins into precisely defined 3-dimensional nanostructures. Polymers are long chain organic molecules and are found in many facets of everyday life that utilize plastics, including food packaging, structural materials for automotive and aerospace transportation, and lightweight electronic devices. This project seeks to understand how synthetic polymers can mimic the nanostructure forming abilities of proteins at a very fundamental level. Ultimately, precisely defined synthetic nanostructures could impact technologies ranging from pharmaceuticals to biotechnology and electronics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the course of this award, we developed approaches to stabilize micelles and particles through grafted polymer chains. Our goal was to create very small particles, stable towards flocculation, that could be, in future work, used as catalyst substrates. The small size of the particles would have significant advantages in terms of mass transport, and the use of synthetic rather than biological materials would be advantageous in terms of cost, robustness, and availability. Towards this end, we developed new chemistries for growing poly(ethylene oxide) from hydroxyl groups, studied the formation of surface grafted polymer chains, and developed an entirely new approach to forming dense grafts. The work resulted in four articles published in peer-reviewed journals, four presentations at American Chemical Society national meetings, and the support or partial support of three graduate students.

            Our research began with the synthesis of toothbrush polymers: hydrophobic polymers with hydrophilic polymers grafted to one end. Several different polymers were synthesized, with variations in the density and length of the grafts. We found that when these polymers were slowly changed from a nonselective solvent (one that dissolved both the hydrophilic and hydrophobic chains), to a selective solvent (one that only dissolved the hydrophilic chains), micelles were formed. The structure of these micelles was strongly influenced by the architecture of the toothbrush polymer. These results were published, and led us to explore other grafted systems.

            One such system was hydroxyl functionalized boron nitride (BN). Such a material had never before been reported, and being able to suspend BN sheets without flocculation could lead to an entirely new catalyst support with very high surface area owing to the molecularly thin sheets. We were successful in growing poly(methyl methacrylate) from the edges of the sheets, forming stable suspensions in organic solvents. This work was also published, and is continuing with other funding.

            The final aspect of the work supported by this grant was to study and improve the dense grafting found at surfaces. Grafting chains at surfaces creates polymer brushes that have desirable properties such as low friction and low adhesion. Creating a high surface area substrate using a fibrous nylon filter allowed us to directly study such surfaces, and show experimentally for the first time that a significant percentage of the grafted polymer chains were very short and did not contribute to the surface properties. This work has been published, and it suggests that there is an upper limit to the densities obtainable by current methods. This led us to devise a new approach to creating these brush materials that involves supplying the monomers that grow the grafted polymers from below the surface rather than from above the surface. This creates an environment in which the concentration of monomers is highest near the surface, meaning the reactive polymer chain ends that are attached to the shortest polymer chains see a higher concentration of monomers than do the longer chains. The result is that the short chains grow faster than the longer chains, and the final polymer brush has much more uniform chain lengths. In the commonly used method, the situation is reversed, meaning the longer chains grow faster than the shorter ones, and the final brushes end up being of very different lengths. Our investigations have been published and presented in several recent lectures. Applications for our new technique include providing very low friction surfaces for artificial hips to avoid the need for repeat surgery.

Our goal was to create very small particles, stable towards flocculation, that could be, in future work, used as catalyst substrates. The small size of the particles would have significant advantages in terms of mass transport, and the use of synthetic rather than biological materials would be advantageous in terms of cost, robustness, and availability. The work resulted in four articles published in peer-reviewed journals, four presentations at American Chemical Society national meetings, and the support or partial support of three graduate students.
